utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: All right, I’m ready for my next question.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: In a world where rhinoceroses are domesticated pets, who wins the Second World War?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Uganda.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Defend.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Kenya rises to power on the export of rhinoceroses. A Central African power block is formed, colonizing North Africa and Europe. When war breaks out, no one can afford the luxury of a rhino. Kenya withers, Uganda triumphs.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Correct. My turn.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: In a world where a piano is a weapon, not a musical instrument, on what does Scott Joplin play The Maple Leaf Rag?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Tuned bayonets.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Defend.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Isn’t it obvious?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You’re right. My apologies.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What the hell are you guys playing?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It’s a game we invented. It’s called Counterfactuals.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: We postulate an alternate world that differs from ours in one key aspect and then pose questions to each other.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It’s fun for ages eight to eighty. Join us.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: All right. I like a good brainteaser. Give it a whirl.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You’re in luck, this is an easy one. In a world where mankind is ruled by a giant intelligent beaver, what food is no longer consumed?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Uh, a BLT where the B stands for beaver? I don’t know.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Leonard, be serious. We’re playing a game here.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I can figure this out, let’s see. Um, well, beavers eat tree bark. The only tree bark I know that humans consume is cinnamon. So, I’ll say cinnamon.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Incorrect. Obviously, the answer is cheese Danish.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: In a world ruled by a giant beaver, mankind builds many dams to please the beaver overlord. The low-lying city of Copenhagen is flooded. Thousands die. Devastated, the Danes never invent their namesake pastry. How does one miss that?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: This is ridiculous. You’re just making stuff up.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Is he always like this when he loses?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, yes. You should’ve been here for the great Jenga tantrum of 2008.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You bumped the table and you know it.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Perhaps it would be kinder to play a game more suited to his abilities. We’ll close our eyes and count to ten while you hide.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’m going to my room.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Very good, Leonard. But next time, don’t tell us where you’re hiding.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Did you guys see the paper in The American Physics Journal on supersolids? It’s pretty interesting. This guy’s working from a hypothesis where…

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Spoiler alert! Spoiler alert.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Don’t ruin it for me, man. I printed out a PDF to read on the potty.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: On the potty? What are you, five?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: It’s a potty. What do you call it?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Toilet.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: That’s a little vulgar for the dinner table, don’t you think?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh, and potty is okay?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Potty is innocent. Potty is adorable.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: What do you do in the potty, wee-wee?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: If I don’t have to boom-boom.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Greetings. You all remember Amy Farrah Fowler.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sure.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Nice to see you.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Hello.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Sorry we’re late.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I must take responsibility. I had to stop for feminine hygiene supplies.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Ah, ah.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I believe she’s experiencing her menses.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Actually, I’m not. In order to avoid surprises, I wear them all the time.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Ah, ah.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay. Toilet’s sounding pretty good now, huh?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Hey, look, it’s Shamy.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Shamy?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: A juvenile amalgamation of our names. Sheldon and Amy, Shamy.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Oh. I don’t like that. Don’t do that.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: All righty. What’s new?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Well, just recently, I learned that you refer to us as Shamy, and I don’t like that.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I got it. But what I was going for was, you know, how’s your life?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Like everybody else’s. Subject to entropy, decay and eventual death. Thank you for asking. Why is she not taking our order?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I should’ve warned you, one has to navigate a labyrinth of social nonsense before one can be fed here.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Really? I assumed an establishment called the Cheesecake Factory would function more efficiently.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It’s how they lure you in. I believe it’s called bait and switch.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, I’m just gonna walk away, ’cause I don’t want to be here.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: So, this is nice. First time we’ve all gotten together to eat.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: You’re right, he’s a festival of humdrum chitchat.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, that’s all I got. Howard, you’re up.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Um, tell us about your work, Amy.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I doubt you’d understand. Sheldon tells me you only have a master’s degree.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Raj, do you have any questions for Amy?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I’m curious as to why we’re not eating alone.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: They can’t function without me. I’m the social glue that holds this little group together. You’re welcome.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Listen, can I talk to you about your girlfriend?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: She’s not my girlfriend. She’s a girl and she’s my friend, but there’s no touching or unsanitary exchange of saliva.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Got it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Although, for the record, on one occasion, she licked her thumb to remove raspberry jelly from the corner of my mouth. It’s an action we both regret to this day.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Uh-huh. Anyway, I’m not sure she’s the best fit for our little, how should we call it, rebel alliance.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, I never identified with the rebel alliance. Despite their tendency to build Death Stars, I’ve always been more of an empire man.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, not my point.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I know what your point is. You’re intimidated by Amy’s intellect. To that I say, buck up.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, let me just get right to it. Amy is judgmental, sanctimonious and frankly just obnoxious.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: So?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: So we already have you for all that.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Are you suggesting I terminate my relationship with Amy?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, no, of course not. Just have your relationship someplace else.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: May I point out that for eight long months, I suffered in silence as your female companion filled our apartment with her off-key country music caterwauling, the unappetizing spectacle of her grinding a pumice stone against her calloused feet in our living room, and night after night of uninformative TV documentaries about the Jersey Shore.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Suffered in silence?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes. And I’d thank you to do the same.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Really? Silence?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Ah. Nothing makes beer taste better than cool clear Rocky Mountain spring water. Where are the Rocky Mountains, anyway?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Philadelphia.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Really? I thought they were out West someplace.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Think about it, Raj. Where did the movie Rocky take place?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Philadelphia. Okay, now I get it.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: So this is the plan? From now on, we’re just gonna hide out in here to avoid the Shamy?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I’m very comfortable here. Penny, dear, why don’t you shoot another silver bullet my way?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Get one yourself.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Ooh, somebody’s been taking bitchy pills.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: God, he’s an ass when he drinks.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh, he’s an ass when he doesn’t. You just don’t hear it.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I think we need to start entertaining the possibility that the Shamy could go on for years.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Well, if that’s the case, Penny will have to get satellite TV and maybe once a week run a vacuum through this place.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I thought you were going to talk to Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I did.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, what’d he say?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, he pointed out that he kinda, sorta had to put up with you.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Kinda, sorta had to?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I didn’t agree with him.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, you defended me, right?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I tried, but he made a fairly well-reasoned argument.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: You’re not doing that right.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Gimme.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Trust me.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No!

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I do this for my mom all the time. See? With the grain.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Wow, that is better.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: And someday, when you have varicose veins, I’ll show you how to massage them.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh, God, never again.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I assume by never again, you mean never again will you drink all of Penny’s beer, then run down to the gas station for a couple of 40s, a box of Slim Jims and the latest issue of Bombay Badonkadonks.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I was homesick.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: The highlight of the evening was when you showed us your Bollywood break dancing skills.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: That’s very offensive.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yeah, we all thought so.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, no.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: John and Yoko.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: More like Yoko and Yoko.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Greetings.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I brought Amy here to show her some of the work I’m doing.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: It’s very impressive, for theoretical work.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Do I detect a hint of condescension?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I’m sorry, was I being too subtle? I meant compared to the real-world applications of neurobiology, theoretical physics is, what’s the word I’m looking for? Hmm, cute.

utterance.speaker: Leonard and Howard together
utterance.content: Oooh!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Are you suggesting the work of a neurobiologist like Babinski could ever rise to the significance of a physicist like Clarke-Maxwell or Dirac?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I’m stating it outright. Babinski eats Dirac for breakfast and defecates Clarke-Maxwell.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You take that back.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Absolutely not. My colleagues and I are mapping the neurological substrates that subserve global information processing, which is required for all cognitive reasoning, including scientific inquiry, making my research ipso facto prior in the ordo cognoscendi. That means it’s better than his research, and by extension, of course, yours.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’m sorry, I’m-I’m still trying to work on the defecating Clark Maxwell, so…

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Excuse me, but a grand unified theory, insofar as it explains everything, will ipso facto explain neurobiology.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Yes, but if I’m successful, I will be able to map and reproduce your thought processes in deriving a grand unified theory, and therefore, subsume your conclusions under my paradigm.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That’s the rankest psychologism, and was conclusively revealed as hogwash by Gottlob Frege in the 1890s!

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: We appear to have reached an impasse.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I agree. I move our relationship terminate immediately.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Seconded.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: There being no objections…

utterance.speaker: All
utterance.content: No, uh-uh.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: The motion carries. Good day, Amy Farrah Fowler.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Good day, Sheldon Cooper.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Women, huh? Can’t live with them, can’t successfully refute their hypotheses.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Amen to that.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Hey, Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Hello.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I hear you broke up with Amy.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: A breakup would imply she was my girlfriend. She was a girl who was my friend who is now a girl who is not my friend.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Wow. That’s like the worst country song ever. So, how are you doing?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Regarding what?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Amy.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I don’t follow.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, breakups, or whatever the hell this is, can be tough.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Penny, I assure you, I’m fine. My relationship with Amy was purely intellectual. There were no emotional bonds, the severing of which would cause me any discomfort. The relationship simply outlived its utility, and I’m continuing on with my life as before.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay. Good.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’m off to buy a pussycat.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I gotta tell you guys, I’m a little worried about Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: We’re all a little worried about Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, I mean since the Shamy hit a reef.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh, I thought you were just making a generalization, you know, I’m worried about Sheldon someday setting off a low-yield nuclear device because the cafeteria ran out of lime Jell-O.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: What does hit a reef mean?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Uh, went splitsville.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Pardon?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Turned to boom-boom.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Ah.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I think Sheldon really misses Amy.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: You should lend him your copy of Bombay Badonkadonks.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: He got a cat to keep him company.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: You’re kidding.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: He takes it everywhere, to bed, to the bathroom.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: He takes the kitty to the potty?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I thought we discussed the P-word.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Don’t try to change me, dude. I am what I am.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, gentlemen.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Hey. Aren’t you going to introduce us to your little friend?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: My apologies. Raj, Howard, I’d like you to meet Dr. Robert Oppenheimer.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Hello.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Hi.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Now, if you’ll excuse me, the father of the atomic bomb wants a saucer of milk.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay, I get it. We’re worried about Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hey. Oh, no.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Robert Oppenheimer was lonely.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: So you decided to get the whole Manhattan Project?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes. This is Enrico Fermi, Richard Feynman, Edward Teller, Otto Frisch, and Zazzles.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Zazzles?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I was going to name him Herman von Helmholtz, but he’s so zazzy.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, we need to talk.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: About what?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Cats, Sheldon. You’re clearly upset about Amy being gone, and you’re trying to replace her with a bunch of cats.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Clowder.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: A group of cats is a clowder. Or a glaring.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, yeah, fine.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It’s the kind of thing you ought to know now that we have one.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Terrific. My-my point is you need to face up to what you’re feeling with this breakup.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It wasn’t a breakup. A breakup would imply that Amy was my girlfriend.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, I got it, I got it, she’s not your girlfriend. Now listen to me. I know about loneliness. I know about trying to replace someone with other stuff. When I broke up with Penny, I got back into my cello, I built a bunch of model rockets, I got those weightlifting gloves and that five-pound dumbbell.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You didn’t break up, she dumped you.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: She didn’t dump me. It was mutual!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I was there. She dumped you.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, fine. Live with cats. Be like my Aunt Nancy. She had dozens of them. And do you know what happened after she died? They ate her.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You don’t have to sell me on cats, Leonard. I’m already a fan. All right, fellas, who’s in the mood for Fancy Feast? Well, that’s not fancy at all.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hi, Mrs. Cooper. Thanks for coming.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Where is he?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: He’s in his bedroom.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Now, when you said on the phone he broke up with a girl, you meant an actual girl, not something you kids whipped up in a lab?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, she’s real.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Did they sin?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, no, it’s not like that. It’s, uh, I don’t know what it’s like. But there is something I should prepare you for.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Oh, relax, Leonard, I have raised that boy. I’ve seen him at his best, I’ve seen him at his worst. There’s nothing he can do that’ll surprise me.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hold on to that thought.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Come in.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Surprise.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Mom, what an unexpected pleasure.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: My, my, that’s a powerful smell.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’d like you to meet Oppenheimer, Frisch, Panofsky, Feynman, Weisskopf…

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Yeah, I get it. You got a lot of cats and you gave ’em cute Jewish names.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What are you doing here?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Leonard called, and he said that you were pining for a young lady.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, that’s preposterous. I’m not pining over anyone.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Oh, lambchop, we can quibble what to call it, but I think we can both agree it’s creepy.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I do not agree. Cats make wonderful companions. They don’t argue or question my intellectual authority, and this little guy here, I think you’ll find to be quite zazzy.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: You should have called sooner.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Shelly! Dinner’s ready!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Coming!

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: No cats!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Aw. What is she doing here?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: I called her.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Your mother thinks you might be losing your mind over me. As a neurobiologist, I was curious.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, rest assured, I am in full possession of my faculties.

utterance.speaker: Leonard (pretending to sneeze)
utterance.content: 25 cats!

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Oh, God bless you, dear. Sheldon, sit down. Let’s talk.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: All right, but you’re not fooling me. Whenever you say we have to talk, it means you want me to listen.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Then stop talking.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes, ma’am.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Now, the reason I called Amy over was to find out what type of person she is. And after chatting a bit, I have to say that while she is a perfectly unique young woman, you two are definitely not suited for each other.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That’s a peculiar conclusion. By any standard, Amy is more similar to me than anyone I’ve ever met.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Oh, I’m sorry, Shelly, I can’t see it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, whether you see it or not is irrelevant. I can’t see subatomic particles, but nevertheless, they’re there.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Excellent point.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: A physics point.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Touche.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Well, putting aside the pig Latin, it’s a good thing that you two decided to end the relationship so I didn’t have to end it for you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Amy, after consideration, I believe we may have acted rashly. I propose we resume our relationship and attempt to resolve our differences.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I’ll agree to that only if you’ll stipulate that 80% of our difficulties were caused by you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’ll go as high as 40.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Sixty-five.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Done. You understand that moving forward, we deal with the fact that my mother does not approve of you?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I do. I find being cast in the role of bad girl oddly titillating.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Would you like to see my cats?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I would. I love cats. They’re the epitome of indifference.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Ah, then you may find Zazzles a little cloying.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I saw what you did there.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: He thinks he’s such a smarty pants. He’s no different from any man. You tell ’em not to do something, that’s all they want to do. If I hadn’t told my brother Stumpy not to clear out the wood chipper by hand, we’d still be calling him Edward. Now, don’t you move. I’ll bring over all the food.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, no, no, I can do it.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Well, isn’t that sweet?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Thank you, Amy. Here’s your cat. And here’s your $20.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Next!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Thank you, Amy. Here’s your cat. And here’s your $20.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Next!
